title: Re: @_@
content:
Well I am also a member of another forum that doesn't have a much higher higher membership as the PCKF does yet that forum moves a LOT faster than this one.

I think it has mostly to do with the people and their lives. Most of us are working or have jobs and are out, or nearly out of high shcool.

Also most people check this like once a day. This is ALSO a forum where people usually don't make topics other than Commander Keen topics... Except for Levellass... she likes to make a lot about politics and religion.

But even in the Miscellaneious section... Most of it is computer or technical information. Topics about moving from EZ-board, Having Adlib sound, the wombat topic. This whole community is geared more for "tech talk" than mindless gabbing about different carbonated beverages of choice. This, the PCKF, no matter how you look at it, is a dry forum. There isn't a lot of humor inter spliced in the posts and most are just... like I said, dry. This is not a bad thing... in fact I think it makes this one of the greatest forums out there. There really are no "noobs" here and the "noobs" that do come are eventually driven out due to lack of... attention really... (Harvey comes to mind...)-----------------------
The end of this post. You may stop reading now.

title: get off my lawn you damn kids
content:
Your profile says you joined in early 2005 (only two years and one week after me), so activity at the PCKF had probably died down by the time you'd joined. I remember reading the forums back in 2003 from a web cafe in Uganda, and everything seemed vibrant and lively. There were people creating comics and 3D models, new fansites and fangames were appearing by the day, and there was plently of discussion (as well as a whole load of arguments and flamewars). Perhaps my memory is exaggerated to some extent, but I definitely remember that it was better back in the day.

Damn I feel old. [img]http://www.classicgaming.com/cc314/msgboard/emotikeen-oldy.gif[/img] [url=http://toxicsheep.com]toxicsheep.com[/url] | [url=http://commanderkeen.org]coming up next...[/url]

title: Re: get off my lawn you damn kids
content:
I think this forum is not active is because it reflects the state of Keen games. There haven't been any new ones since Gameboy (it's not canon, but I thought there never be another Keen game, Tom Hall, or non-hall). So really the only thing that get us more into Keen is to play the existing ones or other fangames & mods.

I think other game forums are more active because active franchises are on the edge of tomorrow, you don't know what will be store in the next game. Keen is not like that. And it can be good, you can play the old Keen games, relive nostalgia, and you come to appreciate the games more, because that's all we have, of official stuff. You also keep track better of what is going on, so the fandom is closely stitched.

Even those of us who have seem to forget how far we've come just to have places like this in the first place, and how much it could all change to improve the nature of our interaction within another five years.

</rant>

Seriously, if I could, I'd drag us all back to windows 3.1. (And give Apple the source code for all upcoming windows releases.)[img]http://img.photobucket.com/albums/v499/Nevad/menbun.gif[/img]

title: Alas.
content:
Aye, DOS could have become so much more with some recoding and proprietor support. It seems Linux is the best bet for a modern DOS-like environment now, but it would be nice if it was as simple as DOS to run.

Of course, FreeDOS keeps the dream alive, but it's wasted on modern hardware. That's why I've got a dedicated DOS machine just a double-Caps Lock + 1 away.

title: Re: Alas.
content:
I loved DOS, on my family's 386, Windows 3.1, not sure have much memory, (very little, when we got Win ME we had barely then).

Then we got a Pentium 166 Mhz and realized what power felt like.

title: Re: Alas.
content:
I agree with Sarah here... you see windows 3.1 was, in my mind better than dealing with command lines. Yeah I know some of you would argue that but just listen to me. I can USE command lines just as easily as 3.1. It is just that I prefer simple icons and such to black and white. (Or "Amber" if you had one of them OOOOOOLD monitors. [img]http://www.classicgaming.com/cc314/msgboard/emotikeen-grin.gif[/img] good stuff!) I am one who simply processes pictures better than words. I have, and always HAVE had trouble forming correct sentences, (Also due to my accent and the way of speaking around here.) and spelling correctly. Screw trying to learn another language... I can't even master my OWN! [img]http://www.classicgaming.com/cc314/msgboard/emotikeen-sad.gif[/img]

But what I DO NOT get is how you could have a perfectly functional GUI and SCREW it up. Okay so I think 95-98 were the superior to 3.1 in every way. Except for instability but that was poor coding on Microsoft's part. But even windows 98 required what? EIGHT megs of memory?! Then microshaft comes out with XP and uh-oh. You suddenly need an 800 MHZ processor and 128 megabytes of memory... yet the GUI looks, more or less EXACTLY THE SAME!

Now with VISTA... I hear you NEED to have a high end video card and a fast processor.

IT IS A FRIGGIN GUI! What would you need a VIDEO CARD for? I want that for games if I want to PLAY games but I don't! That's why I bought their 360 machine. Oh it must be because I have SIX different instances of "SVCHOST.exe" and two different instances of "Tablet.exe" as well as two different "Firefox.exe. and some things I never heard of but are probably viruses running.

I want a simple, sprite stacking GUI that lets me execute executables and manage files with drag and drop. NOT have things I didn't tell it to run running. (Why don't they put start up processes in an easy to manage place like "autoexec.bat"?)

Argh! Whatever that was my rant..

I feel like an old hag now... [img]http://www.classicgaming.com/cc314/msgboard/emotikeen-oldy.gif[/img] -----------------------
The end of this post. You may stop reading now.

title: time to redecorate
content: You can reduce the size of the bloated mess that is XP by a fair bit. The main GUI can be replaced by one of the [url=http://www.bb4win.org]BlackBox for Windows[/url] clones, and many system components can be removed from the install CD with [url=http://www.nliteos.com]nLite[/url]. Using these should provide you with a substantial performance increase.

title: Re: time to redecorate
content:
Since we're far off topic anyway, I always liked Windows 3.1. Now that I put them side by side, I can't spot any huge advantage to the Start Menu, which has always been a pain to navigate. Add Mac-stype Expos and Show desktop plus a decent filer and you've got an ideal interface. ________________

title: Re: While on the topic of OS's
content:
I haven't seen any freeware skinning tools for XP. I would've expected M$ to release one, since it's one of the more interesting elements of their GUI.

IIRK, there are some utilities around that modify the Win3.1 interface to add some features from 98.

It'd be nice to see a project like ReactOS, or that recent project that's based on it, being completed.

Edit: I should also add, I agree entirely with Gal's sentiments regarding the GUI. Windows XP could have been slightly decent, as opposed to merely usable, if it kept more of Win98's simplicity.

And as for Vista... I'm not even going there.

title: Re: While on the topic of OS's
content:
[quote]Quote:[hr]and some things I never heard of but are probably viruses running.[hr][/quote]
Ha ha. No. Processes with unclear names, that's what they are.____________
Don't think of me as an ordinary man.

Even though I am an ordinary man.

Ah, [url=http://DaVince.sitesled.com/]site.[/url]

title: Re: While on the topic of OS's
content:
"Oh it must be because I have SIX different instances of "SVCHOST.exe" and two different instances of "Tablet.exe" as well as two different "Firefox.exe. and some things I never heard of but are probably viruses running."

Well, svchost is the Windows NT Service Host application, which runs services such as networking, workstation service, etc. Other background processes include spoolss.exe (Printer spooler service), smss.exe (Session Manager service), csrss.exe (Win32 Subsystem - user mode part), lsass.exe (Local Security and Authentication subsytem), winlogon.exe (Windows Logon process), services.exe (Service Control Manager), System (the Kernel) and Idle (something like the Kernel). This is for Windows NT 3.1/3.5/3.51/4.0 and Windows 2000/XP/2003/Vista (which are internally known as Windows NT 5.0, 5.1, 5.2 and 6.0).

It's not necessary to learn this anyway.

I had the opportunity to deal with MS-DOS 6.22, but I learned MS-DOS stuff first with Windows 95 DOS-mode part (the one outside of Windows, without win.com, etc.). And I love Linux. I also like Windows NT/2000/XP's command console, but I wish it had more builtin features.------------------------------
[url=http://shadowm2006.sitesled.com/]My website[/url]
[url=http://p072.ezboard.com/fpubliccommanderkeenforumfrm20.showMessage?topicID=12.topic]Get Windows/Linux native LModKeen 2 with integrated FIN2BMP![/url]. You know you want to.

title: Re: While on the topic of OS's
content:
You can use the apparently undocumented "msconfig" command to manage all your startup programs in one place, the only things that aren't listed there are the services, which you can get by running "services.msc".

Don't forget to leave the enterprise-level Microsoft SQL Server running in the background though, Vista (and recent XP versions) use it to store configuration data because, you know, the registry wasn't bloated enough.

title: Re: While on the topic of OS's
content:
Yeah, and don't even think about disabling the Remote Procedure Call service. If you do it (I think you can't do it with MS tools anyway), your installation will be toast, you won't be able to run any programs, the CPU will melt and your screen will explode, probably harming you, your children, your pets or your parents... your anything, and you'll most likely have to pay us all because of the consequences that the event might cause in our random-deflection protectage systems, thus originating a paradox that might cause us all to disappear in an instant explosion!
